title: SliceIndex in std::slice - Rust
markdown:
# SliceIndex in std::slice - Rust

```
pub unsafe trait SliceIndex<T>: Sealedwhere
    T: ?Sized,{
    type Output: ?Sized;

    // Required methods
    fn get(self, slice: &T) -> Option<&Self::Output>;
    fn get_mut(self, slice: &mut T) -> Option<&mut Self::Output>;
    unsafe fn get_unchecked(self, slice: *const T) -> *const Self::Output;
    unsafe fn get_unchecked_mut(self, slice: *mut T) -> *mut Self::Output;
    fn index(self, slice: &T) -> &Self::Output;
    fn index_mut(self, slice: &mut T) -> &mut Self::Output;
}
```

Expand description

A helper trait used for indexing operations.

Implementations of this trait have to promise that if the argument to `get_unchecked(_mut)` is a safe reference, then so is the result.

1.28.0 Â· [source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/slice/index.rs.html#154)

The output type returned by methods.

[source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/slice/index.rs.html#159)

ğŸ”¬This is a nightly-only experimental API. (`slice_index_methods`)

Returns a shared reference to the output at this location, if in bounds.

[source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/slice/index.rs.html#164)

ğŸ”¬This is a nightly-only experimental API. (`slice_index_methods`)

Returns a mutable reference to the output at this location, if in bounds.

[source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/slice/index.rs.html#173)

ğŸ”¬This is a nightly-only experimental API. (`slice_index_methods`)

Returns a pointer to the output at this location, without performing any bounds checking. Calling this method with an out-of-bounds index or a dangling `slice` pointer is _[undefined behavior](https://doc.rust-lang.org/reference/behavior-considered-undefined.html)_ even if the resulting pointer is not used.

[source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/slice/index.rs.html#182)

ğŸ”¬This is a nightly-only experimental API. (`slice_index_methods`)

Returns a mutable pointer to the output at this location, without performing any bounds checking. Calling this method with an out-of-bounds index or a dangling `slice` pointer is _[undefined behavior](https://doc.rust-lang.org/reference/behavior-considered-undefined.html)_ even if the resulting pointer is not used.

[source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/slice/index.rs.html#188)

Returns a shared reference to the output at this location, panicking if out of bounds.

ğŸ”¬This is a nightly-only experimental API. (`slice_index_methods`)

1.73.0 Â· [source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/str/traits.rs.html#278)[Â§](#impl-SliceIndex%3Cstr%3E-for-(Bound%3Cusize%3E,+Bound%3Cusize%3E))

Implements substring slicing for arbitrary bounds.

Returns a slice of the given string bounded by the byte indices provided by each bound.

This operation is _O_(1).

#### [Â§](#panics)Panics

Panics if `begin` or `end` (if it exists and once adjusted for inclusion/exclusion) does not point to the starting byte offset of a character (as defined by `is_char_boundary`), if `begin > end`, or if `end > len`.

[Â§](#associatedtype.Output-1)

1.20.0 (const: unstable) Â· [source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/str/traits.rs.html#163)[Â§](#impl-SliceIndex%3Cstr%3E-for-Range%3Cusize%3E)

Implements substring slicing with syntax `&self[begin .. end]` or `&mut self[begin .. end]`.

Returns a slice of the given string from the byte range \[`begin`, `end`).

This operation is _O_(1).

Prior to 1.20.0, these indexing operations were still supported by direct implementation of `Index` and `IndexMut`.

#### [Â§](#panics-1)Panics

Panics if `begin` or `end` does not point to the starting byte offset of a character (as defined by `is_char_boundary`), if `begin > end`, or if `end > len`.

#### [Â§](#examples)Examples

```
let s = "LÃ¶we è€è™ LÃ©opard";
assert_eq!(&s[0 .. 1], "L");

assert_eq!(&s[1 .. 9], "Ã¶we è€");

// these will panic:
// byte 2 lies within `Ã¶`:
// &s[2 ..3];

// byte 8 lies within `è€`
// &s[1 .. 8];

// byte 100 is outside the string
// &s[3 .. 100];
```

[Run](https://play.rust-lang.org/?code=%23!%5Ballow(unused)%5D%0Afn+main()+%7B%0A++++let+s+=+%22L%C3%B6we+%E8%80%81%E8%99%8E+L%C3%A9opard%22;%0A++++assert_eq!(%26s%5B0+..+1%5D,+%22L%22);%0A++++%0A++++assert_eq!(%26s%5B1+..+9%5D,+%22%C3%B6we+%E8%80%81%22);%0A++++%0A++++//+these+will+panic:%0A++++//+byte+2+lies+within+%60%C3%B6%60:%0A++++//+%26s%5B2+..3%5D;%0A++++%0A++++//+byte+8+lies+within+%60%E8%80%81%60%0A++++//+%26s%5B1+..+8%5D;%0A++++%0A++++//+byte+100+is+outside+the+string%0A++++//+%26s%5B3+..+100%5D;%0A%7D&edition=2021)

[Â§](#associatedtype.Output-2)

1.20.0 (const: unstable) Â· [source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/str/traits.rs.html#402)[Â§](#impl-SliceIndex%3Cstr%3E-for-RangeFrom%3Cusize%3E)

Implements substring slicing with syntax `&self[begin ..]` or `&mut self[begin ..]`.

Returns a slice of the given string from the byte range \[`begin`, `len`). Equivalent to `&self[begin .. len]` or `&mut self[begin .. len]`.

This operation is _O_(1).

Prior to 1.20.0, these indexing operations were still supported by direct implementation of `Index` and `IndexMut`.

#### [Â§](#panics-2)Panics

Panics if `begin` does not point to the starting byte offset of a character (as defined by `is_char_boundary`), or if `begin > len`.

[Â§](#associatedtype.Output-3)

1.20.0 (const: unstable) Â· [source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/str/traits.rs.html#98)[Â§](#impl-SliceIndex%3Cstr%3E-for-RangeFull)

Implements substring slicing with syntax `&self[..]` or `&mut self[..]`.

Returns a slice of the whole string, i.e., returns `&self` or `&mut self`. Equivalent to `&self[0 .. len]` or `&mut self[0 .. len]`. Unlike other indexing operations, this can never panic.

This operation is _O_(1).

Prior to 1.20.0, these indexing operations were still supported by direct implementation of `Index` and `IndexMut`.

Equivalent to `&self[0 .. len]` or `&mut self[0 .. len]`.

[Â§](#associatedtype.Output-4)

1.26.0 (const: unstable) Â· [source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/str/traits.rs.html#474)[Â§](#impl-SliceIndex%3Cstr%3E-for-RangeInclusive%3Cusize%3E)

Implements substring slicing with syntax `&self[begin ..= end]` or `&mut self[begin ..= end]`.

Returns a slice of the given string from the byte range \[`begin`, `end`\]. Equivalent to `&self [begin .. end + 1]` or `&mut self[begin .. end + 1]`, except if `end` has the maximum value for `usize`.

This operation is _O_(1).

#### [Â§](#panics-3)Panics

Panics if `begin` does not point to the starting byte offset of a character (as defined by `is_char_boundary`), if `end` does not point to the ending byte offset of a character (`end + 1` is either a starting byte offset or equal to `len`), if `begin > end`, or if `end >= len`.

[Â§](#associatedtype.Output-5)

1.20.0 (const: unstable) Â· [source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/str/traits.rs.html#333)[Â§](#impl-SliceIndex%3Cstr%3E-for-RangeTo%3Cusize%3E)

Implements substring slicing with syntax `&self[.. end]` or `&mut self[.. end]`.

Returns a slice of the given string from the byte range \[0, `end`). Equivalent to `&self[0 .. end]` or `&mut self[0 .. end]`.

This operation is _O_(1).

Prior to 1.20.0, these indexing operations were still supported by direct implementation of `Index` and `IndexMut`.

#### [Â§](#panics-4)Panics

Panics if `end` does not point to the starting byte offset of a character (as defined by `is_char_boundary`), or if `end > len`.

[Â§](#associatedtype.Output-6)

1.26.0 (const: unstable) Â· [source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/str/traits.rs.html#526)[Â§](#impl-SliceIndex%3Cstr%3E-for-RangeToInclusive%3Cusize%3E)

Implements substring slicing with syntax `&self[..= end]` or `&mut self[..= end]`.

Returns a slice of the given string from the byte range \[0, `end`\]. Equivalent to `&self [0 .. end + 1]`, except if `end` has the maximum value for `usize`.

This operation is _O_(1).

#### [Â§](#panics-5)Panics

Panics if `end` does not point to the ending byte offset of a character (`end + 1` is either a starting byte offset as defined by `is_char_boundary`, or equal to `len`), or if `end >= len`.

[Â§](#associatedtype.Output-7)

1.53.0 Â· [source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/slice/index.rs.html#854)[Â§](#impl-SliceIndex%3C%5BT%5D%3E-for-(Bound%3Cusize%3E,+Bound%3Cusize%3E))

[Â§](#associatedtype.Output-8)

1.15.0 (const: unstable) Â· [source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/slice/index.rs.html#200)[Â§](#impl-SliceIndex%3C%5BT%5D%3E-for-usize)

The methods `index` and `index_mut` panic if the index is out of bounds.

[Â§](#associatedtype.Output-9)

1.15.0 (const: unstable) Â· [source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/slice/index.rs.html#336)[Â§](#impl-SliceIndex%3C%5BT%5D%3E-for-Range%3Cusize%3E)

The methods `index` and `index_mut` panic if:

-   the start of the range is greater than the end of the range or
-   the end of the range is out of bounds.

[Â§](#associatedtype.Output-10)

1.15.0 (const: unstable) Â· [source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/slice/index.rs.html#464)[Â§](#impl-SliceIndex%3C%5BT%5D%3E-for-RangeFrom%3Cusize%3E)

The methods `index` and `index_mut` panic if the start of the range is out of bounds.

[Â§](#associatedtype.Output-11)

1.15.0 (const: unstable) Â· [source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/slice/index.rs.html#510)[Â§](#impl-SliceIndex%3C%5BT%5D%3E-for-RangeFull)

[Â§](#associatedtype.Output-12)

1.26.0 (const: unstable) Â· [source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/slice/index.rs.html#550)[Â§](#impl-SliceIndex%3C%5BT%5D%3E-for-RangeInclusive%3Cusize%3E)

The methods `index` and `index_mut` panic if:

-   the end of the range is `usize::MAX` or
-   the start of the range is greater than the end of the range or
-   the end of the range is out of bounds.

[Â§](#associatedtype.Output-13)

1.15.0 (const: unstable) Â· [source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/slice/index.rs.html#425)[Â§](#impl-SliceIndex%3C%5BT%5D%3E-for-RangeTo%3Cusize%3E)

The methods `index` and `index_mut` panic if the end of the range is out of bounds.

[Â§](#associatedtype.Output-14)

1.26.0 (const: unstable) Â· [source](https://doc.rust-lang.org/1.80.0/src/core/slice/index.rs.html#595)[Â§](#impl-SliceIndex%3C%5BT%5D%3E-for-RangeToInclusive%3Cusize%3E)

The methods `index` and `index_mut` panic if the end of the range is out of bounds.

[Â§](#associatedtype.Output-15)

pub unsafe trait SliceIndex<T>: Sealed
where

    type Output: ?Sized;

    fn get_mut(self, slice: &mut T) -> Option<&mut Self::Output>;
    unsafe fn get_unchecked(self, slice: *const T) -> *const Self::Output;
    unsafe fn get_unchecked_mut(self, slice: *mut T) -> *mut Self::Output;
    fn index(self, slice: &T) -> &Self::Output;
    fn index_mut(self, slice: &mut T) -> &mut Self::Output;
}

impl SliceIndex<str> for (Bound<usize>, Bound<usize>)

Implements substring slicing for arbitrary bounds.

Returns a slice of the given string bounded by the byte indices provided by each bound.

This operation is O(1).

Â§Panics

Panics if begin or end (if it exists and once adjusted for inclusion/exclusion) does not point to the starting byte offset of a character (as defined by is_char_boundary), if begin > end, or if end > len.

Â§

type Output = str

1.20.0 (const: unstable) Â· sourceÂ§

impl SliceIndex<str> for Range<usize>

Implements substring slicing with syntax &self[begin .. end] or &mut self[begin .. end].

Returns a slice of the given string from the byte range [begin, end).

This operation is O(1).

Prior to 1.20.0, these indexing operations were still supported by direct implementation of Index and IndexMut.

Â§Panics

Panics if begin or end does not point to the starting byte offset of a character (as defined by is_char_boundary), if begin > end, or if end > len.

Â§Examples

let s = "LÃ¶we è€è™ LÃ©opard";
assert_eq!(&s[0 .. 1], "L");

assert_eq!(&s[1 .. 9], "Ã¶we è€");

// these will panic:
// byte 2 lies within `Ã¶`:
// &s[2 ..3];

// byte 8 lies within `è€`
// &s[1 .. 8];

// byte 100 is outside the string
// &s[3 .. 100];

impl SliceIndex<str> for RangeFrom<usize>

Implements substring slicing with syntax &self[begin ..] or &mut self[begin ..].

Returns a slice of the given string from the byte range [begin, len). Equivalent to &self[begin .. len] or &mut self[begin .. len].

This operation is O(1).

Prior to 1.20.0, these indexing operations were still supported by direct implementation of Index and IndexMut.

impl SliceIndex<str> for RangeFull

Implements substring slicing with syntax &self[..] or &mut self[..].

Returns a slice of the whole string, i.e., returns &self or &mut self. Equivalent to &self[0 .. len] or &mut self[0 .. len]. Unlike other indexing operations, this can never panic.

This operation is O(1).

Prior to 1.20.0, these indexing operations were still supported by direct implementation of Index and IndexMut.

Equivalent to &self[0 .. len] or &mut self[0 .. len].

impl SliceIndex<str> for RangeInclusive<usize>

Implements substring slicing with syntax &self[begin ..= end] or &mut self[begin ..= end].

Returns a slice of the given string from the byte range [begin, end]. Equivalent to &self [begin .. end + 1] or &mut self[begin .. end + 1], except if end has the maximum value for usize.

This operation is O(1).

Â§Panics

Panics if begin does not point to the starting byte offset of a character (as defined by is_char_boundary), if end does not point to the ending byte offset of a character (end + 1 is either a starting byte offset or equal to len), if begin > end, or if end >= len.
